categories.title: Hyperfy Platform: Technical Developments, Features, and Community Feedback

content.text: The Hyperfy community has been actively discussing and implementing a wide range of technical features and improvements across the platform. Key updates include enhancements to material rendering, mesh linking, mobile editor support, AI systems, and camera controls. Developers like ashxn.eth, .somethingmoreprofessional, and crufro have contributed to refining how materials are updated in real-time, including support for texture scrolling and base color changes via scripting. A pull request (PR #81) was submitted to enable base color changes, with suggestions for improvement provided by ashxn.eth.

Mesh linking behavior was clarified: linked meshes share material instances for performance, while unlinked meshes allow per-instance customization at a performance cost. This is crucial for features like unique color or transparency per object. Additionally, mobile development support was discussed, with proposals for integrating the Monaco editor, voice commands, and mobile-friendly features like autocomplete and clipboard support.

Gameplay systems are also evolving. 0xpeezy implemented a mob respawn system with lock-on targeting and is working on hitboxes and visual feedback. ashxn.eth introduced a modular mob AI system with defined behavior phases, and a new Prism PvPvE system featuring class-based avatars, skills, and energy mechanics. PvP toggling and inventory systems are planned.

Camera functionality was expanded with a camera manager supporting static, panning, and orbit modes, including path-based transitions. Material mounting timing was explained to help developers understand when properties become script-accessible. GPU hosting for LLMs was explored, with tools like Runpod.io and Replicate discussed for self-hosting models like Qwen Coder 3B.

In another discussion, the feasibility of recreating games like 'Genji Ball' in Hyperfy was confirmed, with reflect mechanics already supported. However, limitations in LiveKit integration—such as missing voice, screen share, and video features—were noted as barriers to hosting fully interactive events. Suggestions were made to update release language to better reflect Early Access limitations.

Security and moderation were also addressed. A scammer impersonating an admin was quickly removed by 0xpeezy, and hprivakos proposed blocking links from non-$HYPER users to prevent future incidents. Deployment challenges were highlighted by swissverse, who faced issues deploying with Gemini 2.5 and Cursor, prompting calls for better documentation and user-friendly workflows.

Asset optimization and marketplace presentation were key topics in another thread. Voxvienne shared a workflow for creating modular 3D environments using Kenney base textures, achieving high performance with only two draw calls and 500KB file sizes. Techniques for gradient emissions using UV mapping were explained, and plans to add 'snappoints' for easier map assembly were discussed.

Voxvienne also proposed an isometric layout for asset collections in the Hyperfy marketplace, where each item is a .hyp file for drag-and-drop use. Hprivakos confirmed the idea is feasible but deferred implementation to szjanko, who manages the marketplace. Documentation needs were identified for asset workflows and marketplace features.

categories.title: Hyperfy Platform: Technical Developments, Community Feedback, and Feature Roadmap

content.text: The Hyperfy platform has seen a wide range of technical discussions and feature developments, particularly around asset customization, scripting capabilities, and user experience improvements. A major focus was on texture scrolling and material updates, where contributors like ashxn.eth and .somethingmoreprofessional explored how to dynamically control material properties using app.on('update') and mesh unlinking. A pull request (PR #81) was submitted by crufro to enable base color changes via script, with suggestions for refinement provided by ashxn.eth.

Mesh linking behavior was clarified: linked meshes share material instances for performance, while unlinked meshes allow per-instance customization at a performance cost. This is crucial for developers aiming to implement unique visual effects like transparency or color changes per object.

On the gameplay side, 0xpeezy implemented a mob respawn system with lock-on targeting and phase-based AI behavior, as outlined by ashxn.eth. The Prism system was introduced as a new PvPvE framework featuring class-based avatars, energy mechanics, and a planned PvP toggle. Camera system enhancements were also made, including support for static, panning, and orbit modes with path-based transitions.

Mobile editor support was discussed, with suggestions for integrating the Monaco editor and voice commands. Limitations on iOS were noted, and features like jump, autocomplete, and clipboard support were proposed to improve mobile coding experiences.

In terms of AI and infrastructure, mattimus explored GPU hosting options for running local LLMs like Qwen Coder 3B, with community members recommending services such as Runpod.io and Replicate. Gemini 2.5 Pro was praised for its architectural understanding when used in the Cursor IDE.

Another major thread focused on the feasibility of recreating games like 'Genji Ball' in Hyperfy. ashxn.eth confirmed that the platform supports necessary mechanics like reflect, validating its potential for complex gameplay. However, limitations in LiveKit integration—such as missing voice, screen share, and video—were flagged as critical gaps for event hosting. 0mka_ suggested updating release language to better reflect these limitations.

Security and moderation were also addressed. hprivakos proposed blocking links from non-$HYPER users to prevent scams, and 0xpeezy promptly removed a user impersonating an admin, demonstrating active community moderation.

Asset optimization was a key topic in another discussion led by voxvienne, who shared a workflow for creating modular 3D environments using Kenney base textures. These assets are highly optimized, with entire maps exported at just 500KB and two draw calls. Techniques like top-down UV unwrapping for gradient emissions and plans for adding 'snappoints' to aid map assembly were detailed.

Voxvienne also proposed improvements to the Hyperfy marketplace, including an isometric layout for asset collections and drag-and-drop functionality for individual .hyp files. While the marketplace is managed by szjanko, hprivakos acknowledged the feasibility of these suggestions.
Lastly, the current price of SOL (Solana) was noted at $129.40, though this was not directly tied to the technical discussions.
